paragraph.paragraph:
The diagram tool uses the
http://www.eiffel.com/products/bon.xml BON (Business Object Notation) to represent Eiffel systems. This article will give a summary of all components of an EiffelStudio diagram. For detailed information on BON, please read
http://bon-method.com/book.htm Seamless Object-Oriented Software Architecture by Kim Waldén and Jean-MarcNerson, Prentice Hall 1994.
paragraph.heading: 2Class
paragraph.paragraph: /images/eiffelstudio/diagram/bon-class.png An object class is represented by an ellipse(sometimes referred to as bubble). It contains the class name and formal generics of the Eiffel class it represents. Second, it displays information about properties of a class. These properties are:

list.item:
Deferred: class is declared as
deferred .
/images/eiffelstudio/diagram/bon-class-deferred.png

Effective: class is not
deferred and has at least one
deferred parent, or redefines one ore more features.
/images/eiffelstudio/diagram/bon-class-effective.png

Persistent: class inherits STORABLE or has indexing tag
persistent .
/images/eiffelstudio/diagram/bon-class-persistent.png

Interfaced: class has one ore more
external features.
/images/eiffelstudio/diagram/bon-class-interfaced.png

Reused: class resides in a precompiled library or in a
library cluster.
/images/eiffelstudio/diagram/bon-class-reused.png

Root class: class has the program's entry point.
/images/eiffelstudio/diagram/bon-class-root.png

paragraph.heading: 2Cluster
paragraph.paragraph: A cluster is a collection of classes and sub-clusters. It is represented by a stippled, rounded rectangle. The cluster name is in a similar rectangle, by default located at the top of the cluster just outside of it. A cluster can be iconified, which means it is minimized to take up as less space as possible.
paragraph.heading: 2Inheritance links
paragraph.paragraph: Inheritance between classes is represented by an arrow from a class to its parent. Typically, inheritance links point upwards.
paragraph.heading: 2Client/supplier links
paragraph.paragraph:
Client relationships between classes are represented by an arrow with a double line from the client to the supplier. Typically, these links point to the right. A special kind of relationship is the aggregate client/supplier link. Aggregate means that the supplier is an integral part of the client. In the class text, it corresponds to
expanded features. In the diagram, an aggregate link has a little line along the back side of the arrow.
